Award.AwardTitle: Research in higher dimensional algebraic geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator will work on several problems in higher dimensional algebraic geometry. In a project, joint with Alexeev, Hassett, and Kollár, the PI plans to complete the proof of existence of a coarse moduli space of stable log surfaces and higher dimensional varieties, an analog of the moduli space of stable curves. This an open problem whose solution is crucial to many applications in the field. Another project, pursued jointly by Kollár and the PI, will provide crucial results for the above projects. The main theme of the project is to understand deformations of singularities that appear on stable log varieties. In a related project the PI is planning to prove various generalizations of the classical Kodaira vanishing theorem. In another project the PI is going to work on the refined Viehweg conjecture regarding subvarieties of moduli stacks of canonically polarized smooth projective varieties. This conjecture evolved from a landmark conjecture of Shafarevich, and its solution by Arakelov and Parshin, which played an important role in Faltings' proof of the Mordell Conjecture. Part of this project is joint work with Kebekus. In another project the PI and Hacon are going to study the impact of the existence of nowhere vanishing differential forms on the geometry of the underlying variety. Their goal is to prove several outstanding conjectures in the area. In another project the PI is planning to prove a a characterization of the projective space and quadric hypersurfaces that will give a far reaching common generalization of Mori's theorem (earlier known as Hartshorne's conjecture) and Beauville's conjecture. The latter was settled by Araujo, Druel and the PI recently. In yet another project the PI hopes to prove a strong rational resolution theorem. One application of this result would be that varieties with rational singularities admit a compactification with only rational singularities themselves.

This research is in the field of algebraic geometry, one of the oldest parts of modern mathematics, but one that blossomed to the point where it has solved problems that have stood for centuries. Originally, and still in its simplest form it treats figures defined in the plane by polynomials. Today, the field uses methods not only from algebra, but also from analysis and topology, and conversely it is extensively used in those fields. Moreover it has proved itself useful in fields as diverse as physics, theoretical computer science, cryptography, coding theory and robotics. A central problem in algebraic geometry is the classification of all geometric objects. In turn, an important part of classification theory is the theory of moduli. The latter's core idea is that one does not only want to understand these objects, but also understand the way they can be deformed. Moduli spaces play a very important role in theoretical physics. Studying curves on moduli spaces provides information on how an object is changing in space-time. One of the focuses of this project is on compact moduli spaces. Those are extensions of moduli spaces in general and they give additional information about singular deformations, ones that are essentially different from others. Other goals of the project involve a better understanding of certain higher dimensional varieties.

Introduction

The main goal of the project is to work on several problems in higher dimensional algebraic geometry. These include many subprojects that are all geared toward classification theory.

Classification theory can be divided into two major parts. In one part, the goal is to find relatively simple models of all algebraicly defined geometric objects and describe the way to obtain these models. This part is called "birational geometry". The other major part of classification theory studies these models obtained in the first part. This second part is called "moduli theory". In particular moduli theory studies how these models may be deformed into one another. 

It has been discovered several decades ago that in order to advance either of the above fields one needs to work with singularities and hence understanding the singularities that occur on the models biration geometry produces is essential.

Intellectual Merit

The PI proposed several projects in birational geometry and moduli theory and obtained many results along the lines described and envisioned in the original proposal. 

In particular, Kollár and the PI proved the long standing conjecture that log canonical singularities are Du Bois. This result has already had many applications, for instance in moduli theory. It was published in the Journal of the American Mathematical Society. Lieblich and the PI proved a higher dimensional analog of Shafarevich's conjecture on boundedness of families of canonically polarized varieties. This result was published in the Annals of Mathematics. Greb, Kebekus, Peternell, and the PI proved a fundamental extension result for differential forms on log canonical spaces. This result was published in The Publications Mathématiques de l'IHÉS. Kebekus and the PI proved several results related to Viehweg's conjecture. In particular, they proved a strong form of the conjecture in the case that the base of the family is up to 3 dimensional. These results were published in Inventiones Mathematicae and the Duke Mathematical Journal. Schwede and the PI proved that Du Bois singularities are invariant under small deformations. This had been an open question for several decades. It will be published in a volume of the Advanced Studies in Pure Mathematics. The Pi introduced the notion of Du Bois pairs and proved a vanishing theorem for log canonical singularities using them. He also proved several other results concerning Du Bois singularities. These were published in various books and journals. 

Broader Impact

The two books published provide much needed reference in the subject for new results in the field. They will likely be used as a textbook for advanced courses as well as a standard reference for researchers. The other research projects dealt with important open problems in higher dimensional geometry.Their solutions advanced the knowledge in this field. The educational activities are likely to have very broad impact: The website Situs Geometriae Algebraicae started by the PI led to the launch of the immensely successful website mathoverflow.net serving the entire mathematical community. The PI is also actively involved in promoting mathematics to high school students.He is a regular lecturer at the annual MathDay at the University of Washingtonand the Academic Director of the Summer Institute for Mathematics at the University of Washington (http://simuw.net). In these roles he has an excellent opportunity to positively influence themathematical understanding of many high school students. as well as undergraduatestudents serving as teaching assistants and counselors.
